snippet: Roughly 50,000 men persecuted for homosexuality after World War II have yet to have the convictions stricken from their police records. But that could change in an election year.
abstract: Germany's failure to expunge arrests of victims of legal system that kept Nazi-era ban on homosexuality on books for decades after World War II is indicative of slow pace of reforms on gay equality, despite country's generally liberal populace; roughly 50,000 men persecuted after war have yet to have convictions of sodomy stricken from their police records.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 50,000 men persecuted for homosexuality after World War II have yet to have the convictions stricken from their police records. But that could change in an election year.

headline.seo: Old Homosexuality Laws Still Hang Over Many in Germany
headline.main: Old Homosexuality Laws Still Hang Over Many in Germany
headline.print_headline: Old Homosexuality Laws Still Hang Over Many in Germany
